Rate = 200 ÷ 5 = 40.0 miles per gallon
Distance = 40.0 × 15 = 600 miles

problems.prompt: A student answered 85% of the 60 questions correctly on a test. How many were incorrect?
A store has a 25% off sale, followed by an additional 10% off the discounted price. If an item was originally $100, what's the final price?
A computer originally priced at $1000 is discounted by 10%. After tax of 8%, what's the total price?
A city's population grows from 450000 to 570000 in 2 years. What is the approximate annual percent growth rate (assuming constant yearly growth)?
problems.solution:
Total increase = 120000
Percent = 26.7%
Annual ≈ 13.3% per year

problems.prompt: A water tank loses 15% of its water due to leakage. If it initially had 300 liters, how much water is left?
A student splits 15 study hours among 3 subjects in a 2:3:4 ratio. How many hours are spent on the second subject?
problems.solution:
Total parts = 9
Each part = 15 ÷ 9 = 1.6666666666666667 hours
Second subject = 3 × 1.6666666666666667 = 5.0 hours

3x = 38

It's a right triangle.

problems.prompt: A square and a circle have the same perimeter. The square has side length 12 cm. What is the area of the circle? (Use π ≈ 3.14)
problems.solution:
Square perimeter = 4 × 12 = 48 cm
Circle: 2πr = 48 → r = 7.64 cm
Area = π × r² = 3.14 × 7.64² = 183.44 cm²

Triangle: 72 = (1/2) × 20 × h
h = 7.2 cm

Solving: a = 28, c = 32

packets.title: Punnett Squares, Exponential Growth/Decay, and Experimental Design

problems.prompt: In an organism, Black (B) is dominant over brown (b), and Brown (E) is dominant over blue (e). Two organisms heterozygous for both traits are crossed. What is the probability of offspring with both recessive traits?
problems.solution:
Each trait: Aa x Aa gives 1/4 chance of aa
Both recessive: 1/4 × 1/4 = 1/16

problems.prompt: A man with blood type A (genotype AO) and a woman with blood type B (genotype BO) have a child. What blood types are possible for the child?
problems.answer: Type A, Type B, Type AB, or Type O
problems.solution:
Possible combinations: AO (Type A), BO (Type B), AB (Type AB), OO (Type O)
All four blood types are possible

problems.prompt: A carrier female (XHXh) for an X-linked recessive disorder has a child with a normal male (XHY). What is the probability of a son with the disorder?
problems.solution:
Possible offspring: XHXH, XHXh (daughters), XHY, XhY (sons)
XhY has disorder, probability = 1/4

problems.prompt: In snapdragons, red (RR) × white (WW) produces pink (RW). If two pink flowers are crossed, what percentage will be red?
problems.solution:
RW × RW gives: RR (red), RW (pink), RW (pink), WW (white)
1 out of 4 = 25% red

problems.prompt: A tall, yellow pea plant (TTYY) is crossed with a short, green plant (ttyy). What is the genotype of all F1 offspring?
problems.solution:
TTYY can only give TY gametes
ttyy can only give ty gametes
All offspring: TtYy

problems.prompt: Two organisms with genotype TtYy are crossed. What is the phenotypic ratio of the F2 generation?
problems.solution:
TtYy × TtYy gives classic dihybrid ratio:
9 dominant for both : 3 dominant for first only : 3 dominant for second only : 1 recessive for both

problems.prompt: A cat heterozygous for black fur (Bb) and short fur (Ss) is crossed with a cat with brown, long fur (bbss). What fraction will have black, short fur?
problems.solution:
Bb × bb: 1/2 chance of Bb (black)
Ss × ss: 1/2 chance of Ss (short)
Both: 1/2 × 1/2 = 1/4

problems.prompt: Two carriers (Cc) for an autosomal recessive disorder have a child. What is the probability the child will have the disorder?
problems.solution:
Cc × Cc gives: CC, Cc, Cc, cc
cc has disorder = 1/4 = 25%

problems.prompt: A bird homozygous dominant for beak size (BB) and heterozygous for wing length (Ww) is crossed with a bird with small beak and short wings (bbww). What are the possible offspring genotypes?
problems.solution:
BB can only give B, Ww gives W or w, bbww gives bw
Offspring: BbWw or Bbww

problems.prompt: A plant with dominant phenotype (T_) is test crossed with tt. Half the offspring are tall, half are short. What was the original genotype?
problems.solution:
If Tt × tt: offspring are Tt (tall) and tt (short) in 1:1 ratio
This matches 50/50, so parent was Tt

problems.prompt: In an organism, Tall (T) is dominant over short (t), and Brown (E) is dominant over blue (e). Two organisms heterozygous for both traits are crossed. What is the probability of offspring with both recessive traits?
problems.solution:
Each trait: Aa x Aa gives 1/4 chance of aa
Both recessive: 1/4 × 1/4 = 1/16

problems.prompt: A man with blood type A (genotype AO) and a woman with blood type B (genotype BO) have a child. What blood types are possible for the child?
problems.answer: Type A, Type B, Type AB, or Type O
problems.solution:
Possible combinations: AO (Type A), BO (Type B), AB (Type AB), OO (Type O)
All four blood types are possible

problems.prompt: A carrier female (XHXh) for an X-linked recessive disorder has a child with a normal male (XHY). What is the probability of a son with the disorder?
problems.solution:
Possible offspring: XHXH, XHXh (daughters), XHY, XhY (sons)
XhY has disorder, probability = 1/4

problems.prompt: In snapdragons, red (RR) × white (WW) produces pink (RW). If two pink flowers are crossed, what percentage will be red?
problems.solution:

problems.prompt: A bacterial culture starts with 100 bacteria and triples every 3 hours. How many bacteria after 9 hours?
A radioactive isotope has a half-life of 40 years. Starting with 160 grams, how many years until only 20 grams remain?
problems.solution:
Half-lives needed: 160 → 80.0 → 40.0 → ... → 20
This is 3 half-lives
Time = 3 × 40 = 120 years

problems.prompt: You invest $5000 at 4% interest compounded semi-annually. What is the value after 2 years?
A city population is 400000 and grows at 3% per year. How many years to exceed 440000?
An app has 800 users, increasing by 40% monthly. How many months to exceed 7000 users?
A car depreciates 20% per year. Purchased for $25000, what is its value after 3 years?
A collectible valued at $800 increases 12% yearly. How many years to exceed $1100?
A colony has 40 organisms on day 1 and 160 on day 3. How many on day 5?
problems.solution:
Day 1→3: 40→160 (doubled twice)
Day 3→5: doubles twice more
160 × 4 = 640

problems.prompt: Processing power doubles every 18 months. Starting at 1 unit, what is the power after 6 years?
A patient receives 400 mg of medication with a 6-hour half-life. How much remains after 30 hours?
A bacterial culture starts with 50 bacteria and triples every 3 hours. How many bacteria after 6 hours?
A radioactive isotope has a half-life of 60 years. Starting with 240 grams, how many years until only 15 grams remain?
problems.solution:
Half-lives needed: 240 → 120.0 → 60.0 → ... → 15
This is 4 half-lives
Time = 4 × 60 = 240 years

problems.prompt: Seeds are tested at 10°C, 15°C, 20°C, 25°C, and 30°C for germination. What is a potential flaw?
problems.answer: No control/standard temperature or replication not mentioned
problems.solution: Potential flaws: (1) No control at standard room temperature, (2) No mention of replication/sample size, (3) Assumes optimal is in tested range

problems.prompt: Testing insect repellent, one arm is sprayed, the other isn't (same person). Why is this good design?
problems.answer: Controls for individual variation in attractiveness to insects
problems.solution: Using the same person controls for individual differences in body chemistry, skin type, and attractiveness to insects. Any difference is more likely due to the repellent.

problems.prompt: A student tests if plants grow taller in green light vs. sunny windowsill. After 2 weeks, the windowsill plant is taller. What is the major flaw?
problems.answer: Confounding variable: sunlight is full spectrum, not just green
problems.solution: The flaw is that sunlight contains all colors, not just green. A proper control would be white light of the same intensity as the green light.

problems.prompt: A study finds correlation between exercise and grades. Why can't researchers conclude exercise causes higher grades?
problems.answer: Correlation does not imply causation; confounding variables possible
problems.solution: Confounding variables could explain both: discipline, time management, socioeconomic status. Correlation ≠ causation.

problems.prompt: Testing if salt affects boiling point: heat 500mL pure water, then 500mL salt water. How to improve reliability?
problems.answer: Conduct multiple trials and average the results
problems.solution: Reliability improves with replication. Run multiple trials of each condition and average the results to minimize random error.

problems.prompt: A drug study is double-blind: neither patients nor doctors know who gets the drug vs. placebo. What is the primary advantage?
problems.answer: Eliminates placebo effect and experimenter bias
problems.solution: Double-blind eliminates: (1) Placebo effect from patients, (2) Unconscious bias from doctors evaluating outcomes. Results are based solely on the drug's effects.

problems.prompt: Testing a new teaching method by comparing two different schools. What is a significant confounding variable?
problems.solution: Confounding variables: student socioeconomic background, prior achievement, teacher quality, school resources. These could affect results more than the teaching method.

problems.prompt: Testing how caffeine affects reaction time: participants drink caffeinated beverage then take a test. What control is missing?
problems.solution: Need a control where participants consume a non-caffeinated but otherwise identical beverage, then take the same test.

problems.prompt: Testing battery brands in flashlights, all turned on simultaneously in a room with stable temperature. Why mention stable temperature?
problems.answer: Temperature affects battery performance; must be constant
problems.solution: Temperature affects chemical reactions in batteries. Keeping it stable ensures the only significant difference between groups is the battery brand.

problems.prompt: A study finds correlation between exercise and grades. Why can't researchers conclude exercise causes higher grades?
problems.answer: Correlation does not imply causation; confounding variables possible
problems.solution: Confounding variables could explain both: discipline, time management, socioeconomic status. Correlation ≠ causation.

problems.prompt: Testing if salt affects boiling point: heat 500mL pure water, then 500mL salt water. How to improve reliability?
problems.answer: Conduct multiple trials and average the results
problems.solution: Reliability improves with replication. Run multiple trials of each condition and average the results to minimize random error.

problems.prompt: A drug study is double-blind: neither patients nor doctors know who gets the drug vs. placebo. What is the primary advantage?
problems.answer: Eliminates placebo effect and experimenter bias
problems.solution: Double-blind eliminates: (1) Placebo effect from patients, (2) Unconscious bias from doctors evaluating outcomes. Results are based solely on the drug's effects.

problems.prompt: Testing a new teaching method by comparing two different schools. What is a significant confounding variable?
problems.solution: Confounding variables: student socioeconomic background, prior achievement, teacher quality, school resources. These could affect results more than the teaching method.

problems.prompt: Testing how caffeine affects reaction time: participants drink caffeinated beverage then take a test. What control is missing?
problems.solution: Need a control where participants consume a non-caffeinated but otherwise identical beverage, then take the same test.

problems.prompt: Testing battery brands in flashlights, all turned on simultaneously in a room with stable temperature. Why mention stable temperature?
problems.answer: Temperature affects battery performance; must be constant
problems.solution: Temperature affects chemical reactions in batteries. Keeping it stable ensures the only significant difference between groups is the battery brand.

problems.prompt: A scientist tests if exercise amount affects heart rate. Identify: (a) independent variable, (b) dependent variable, (c) control group, (d) two constants.
problems.answer: (a) exercise amount, (b) heart rate, (c) people at rest, (d) age, fitness level
problems.solution:
Independent variable (manipulated): exercise amount
Dependent variable (measured): heart rate
Control group: people at rest
Constants: age, fitness level

problems.prompt: Seeds are tested at 10°C, 15°C, 20°C, 25°C, and 30°C for germination. What is a potential flaw?
problems.answer: No control/standard temperature or replication not mentioned
problems.solution: Potential flaws: (1) No control at standard room temperature, (2) No mention of replication/sample size, (3) Assumes optimal is in tested range

problems.prompt: Testing insect repellent, one arm is sprayed, the other isn't (same person). Why is this good design?
problems.answer: Controls for individual variation in attractiveness to insects
problems.solution: Using the same person controls for individual differences in body chemistry, skin type, and attractiveness to insects. Any difference is more likely due to the repellent.

packets.title: Energy Transfer, Mass vs. Weight, and Clock Problems

problems.prompt: Primary producers store 35000 kcal. How much energy is available to secondary consumers?
problems.solution:
Primary consumers: 35000 × 0.10 = 3500 kcal
Secondary consumers: 3500 × 0.10 = 350 kcal

problems.prompt: Tertiary consumers have 15 kcal available. How much did primary producers initially capture?
problems.solution:
Work backwards:
Secondary: 15 ÷ 0.1 = 150
Primary: 150 ÷ 0.1 = 1500
Producers: 1500 ÷ 0.1 = 15000 kcal

problems.prompt: Food chain: phytoplankton → zooplankton → small fish → seals. If a seal needs 1500 kcal/day, how much must phytoplankton provide?
problems.solution:
Work backwards through 3 transfers:
Small fish: 1500 ÷ 0.1 = 15000
Zooplankton: 15000 ÷ 0.1 = 150000
Phytoplankton: 150000 ÷ 0.1 = 1500000 kcal

problems.prompt: Primary consumers have 50000 J, tertiary consumers have 600 J. What is the energy transfer efficiency from primary to tertiary?
If 10% of energy transfers between levels, what percentage from producers reaches tertiary consumers?
Producers had 800000 kcal. A fire reduces biomass by 70%. How much energy now available to primary consumers?
An ecosystem has 250000 insects and 1000 birds. Assuming energy transfer is proportional to numbers, what is the efficiency from insects to birds?
Net primary productivity is 10000 kcal/m²/year. Secondary consumers get 100 kcal/m²/year. What is the combined transfer efficiency?
A primary consumer eats 500 J. 180 J lost as waste, 130 J used in respiration. How much available to secondary consumers?
An ecosystem supports 5 tertiary consumers needing 1000 kcal each. With 10% transfer, how many primary consumers if each provides 50 kcal?
problems.solution:
Tertiary total: 5 × 1000 = 5000 kcal
Secondary need: 5000 ÷ 0.1 = 50000
Primary need: 50000 ÷ 0.1 = 500000
Count: 500000 ÷ 50 = 10000

Primary: 250 ÷ 0.1 = 2500
Producers: 2500 ÷ 0.1 = 25000 kcal

problems.prompt: An object has mass 70 kg on Earth. What is its mass on the Moon?
problems.solution: Mass is intrinsic and doesn't change with location. Mass = 70 kg everywhere.

problems.prompt: An astronaut weighs 800 N on Earth. What is their weight on Mars (g = 3.7 m/s²)? Use g_Earth = 10 m/s².
problems.solution:
Mass = 800 / 10 = 80.0 kg

problems.prompt: What is the smaller angle between clock hands at 9:20?
Between 3 and 4 o'clock, when are the hands exactly opposite (180° apart)?
problems.solution:
Hands opposite when they are 180° apart
Minute hand angle = 6m, Hour hand angle = 30h + 0.5m
For 180° apart: 6m - (30×3 + 0.5m) = 180
5.5m = 270
m ≈ 49.1 minutes
Answer: 3:49

problems.prompt: A clock starts at noon. By 20 minutes past 5, how many degrees has the hour hand moved?
problems.solution:
Total time: 5 hours 20 min = 5.33 hours
Hour hand: 30° per hour
Movement: 5.33 × 30° = 160°

problems.prompt: How many times do clock hands form a right angle (90°) in a 12-hour period?
problems.solution:
Hands form right angles twice per hour, but at 3:00 and 9:00 they coincide with regular positions.
Total: 2 × 12 - 2 = 22 times

problems.prompt: A clock loses 5 minutes every hour. Set correctly at 12 PM, what actual time when it shows 4:00 PM?
problems.solution:
Clock shows 4 hours = 240 min
Ratio: 60/55 = 12/11
Actual: 240 × (12/11) ≈ -524 min = 3.3 hours
Actual time: approximately 4:16 PM

problems.prompt: What is the angle between clock hands at 7:20?
Between 7 and 8 o'clock, when are the hands together (coincident)?
problems.solution:
Hands meet when minute hand catches up
Minutes = 7 × (60/11) ≈ 38.2
Time: 7:38

problems.prompt: A clock gains 10 minutes per 24 hours. Set at 8:00 AM Monday, what time does it show at 8:00 PM Tuesday?
problems.solution:
Time elapsed: 36 hours
Gain: (10/24) × 36 = 15 minutes
Clock shows: 8:15 PM

problems.prompt: A clock's minute hand overtakes the hour hand every 65 minutes. How much does it gain in a day?
problems.solution:
Correct overtake time: ≈65.45 min
Gain per cycle: 0.45 min
Cycles per day: 1440/65 ≈ 22.2
Total gain: ≈10 minutes

problems.prompt: What is the reflex angle (larger angle) between clock hands at 10:10?
problems.solution:
Hour hand: 10 × 30° + 10 × 0.5° = 305.0°
Minute hand: 10 × 6° = 60°
Smaller angle: 245°
Reflex angle: 360° - 245° = 245°

problems.prompt: What is the smaller angle between clock hands at 2:15?
Between 1 and 2 o'clock, when are the hands exactly opposite (180° apart)?
problems.solution:
Hands opposite when they are 180° apart
Minute hand angle = 6m, Hour hand angle = 30h + 0.5m

5.5m = 210
m ≈ 38.2 minutes
Answer: 1:38
